I love this trick because it's so much fun to investigate! One of my students showed it to me one day and we worked through it together. Eventually we came up with a great experiment to figure it out. Just flip your card over so you can track it! Before doing this, we assumed it must have been something complex. After we did it, we were surprised at how simple the trick was. It seemed so obvious! I won't reveal how it works, I don't want to spoil the surprise.

I figured out the trick!
The chosen card always goes third from the top of the stack.
Every card number has at least three letters in its name, meaning that the chosen card will always end up third from the bottom of the stack after the number is dealt.
"of" just has two letters, which puts two random cards at the bottom of the stack. This puts the chosen card fifth from the bottom and, since the stack is nine cards tall, fifth from the top.

SOLUTION:

All the possible card numbers (A, 2-10, J, Q, K) have names that are a minimum of 3 letters long, so when you do the first shuffle, you'll place at least the first 3 cards on the table, and because you're counting them out in the way shown in the bottom, you're also reversing the order. Given you place the chosen card 3rd from the top before doing the shuffles, this means that your card will always be one of the cards you put down on the table, and once the first shuffle is complete your card will always be in the 7th position.

The next shuffle is always going to be associated to the word "of" - this will then move your card to the 5th position (2 cards removed from the top).

The last shuffle will also always end up with your card being one placed on the table because the name of every suit has a minimum of 5 letters, and from there on everything is done - the moment you put down your card, there are 4 cards beneath it and you have 4 cards in your hand. Either the suit name is 5 letters and you place the remaining cards in your hand on top, or the suit name is more than 5 letters and you place some more cards down on the table before putting the rest of the cards in your hand on top. Either way it doesn't matter - those 4 cards you had in your hand end up on top of the chosen card and the card ends up in the 5th position.
